title: Is a topological order on the reverse graph the same as a topological order reversed? - Quora

response.answer_text: Let [math]G = (V, E)[/math] be a graph, and let [math]P[/math] be a topological ordering of the nodes in [math]G[/math]. Let [math]G' = (V, E')[/math] be the graph with the edges flipped and [math]P'[/math] be [math]P[/math] reversed. Suppose for a contradiction that [math]P'[/math] is not a topological ordering of [math]G'[/math]. Then, by definition there must be two nodes [math]u[/math] and [math]v[/math] such that [math](v, u) \in E'[/math] and [math]u[/math] comes before [math]v[/math] in [math]P'[/math]. But then, by definition of [math]E'[/math] we have [math](u, v) \in E[/math], and by definition of [math]P'[/math] we must have [math]v[/math] coming before [math]u[/math] in [math]P[/math]. This contradicts that [math]P[/math] is a topological ordering of [math]G[/math]. Thus, [math]P'[/math] must be a topological ordering of [math]G'[/math]. Note: I'd be a little cautious about using the word 'same', since graphs can have multiple topological orderings.
Not at all. If a---->b is a graph then b----->a is reverse graph having 2 vertices and 1 edge. Topological sort of first one would be (a,b) and of second is (b,a). Obviously not same.
